Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Multiwavelength Raman Spectroscopy Facility for Catalysis, Biological, Nanoscale and Materials Research
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI)program and support from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation (CRIF) program, Professor Michael Neidig and collaborators from the University of Rochester will acquire a multiwavelength Raman spectrometer built around a triple spectrometer with multiple laser lines to allow collection of Raman data from the near-IR to near-UV regions. Raman spectroscopy in this region is used to measure the vibrational frequencies of a material. This provides information on the chemical composition and structure of substances. It is a widely used tool to understand the properties of chemical and biological systems and in materials research. The instrument will be a multi-user facility open to users at the university and in the Rochester area including faculty at St. John Fisher College and SUNY-Geneseo. It will advance the training of students in their research and course work at all levels.

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) investigating structure, bonding and mechanism in non-precious metal catalysis for organic syntheses; (b) carrying out ultrafast photochemistry probed by femtosecond stimulated Raman spectroscopy; (c) analyzing biological specimens at the cell and tissue level; (d) studying second-sphere effects in heme proteins and engineered metalloproteins for energy conversion; (e) analyzing compounded prescriptions; (f) elucidating binding conformation of A-beta peptides over gold nanocolloids; and (g) studying hollow microneedles for gene delivery in living cells.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Raman spectroscopy is an experimental technique that allows research scientists to characterize the molecular vibrations of molecules and materials in well-defined species as well as complex mixtures.  This MRI grant has enabled the construction of a new Raman facility at the University of Rochester allowing researchers in the region to harness the capabilities of Raman spectroscopy.  The new facility can perform Raman measurements across a wide range of temperatures (-260 C to room temperature), utilizing lasers ranging from 355 nm to 830 nm with the ability to measure very low vibrational frequencies through the incorporation of a triple spectrometer. This facility positively impacts many areas of research including biology, optics, chemistry and materials science. For example, the facility is already being used to understand active catalyst structures in iron catalysts to enable the rational design and development of effective and sustainable catalysts for applications in pharmaceuticals and fine chemical syntheses. In terms of anticipated applications, the Raman facility can be utilized to directly measure the structure of DNA oligomers, allowing assignment of ultrafast dynamics to specific structures in the structurally inhomogeneous mixture. Measures of vibrational anharmonicity can reveal how heat moves through molecules. Cell and tissue Raman studies could lead to the development of new instrumentation for cell and tissue analysis. This shared facility will also enhance collaboration across the UR campus and between regional universities, including researchers at SUNY-Geneseo and St. John Fisher College who will utilize this facility. This new Raman facility provides important educational benefits through training of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers in Raman spectroscopy. This instrumentation will catalyze frequent contacts between the many users, facilitating graduate student interaction between groups, which often nucleates new ideas and collaborative efforts. Sharing of expertise between students and postdoctoral fellows knowledgeable in catalysis, biological chemistry, optics, organic polymers, biopolymers, nanoscience and device engineering will benefit graduate training across the University of Rochester and at the neighboring institutions that will utilize this facility.
